image.altText: A composite image of Peter Hudson on the left and Magenta Marshall on the right.

props.synopsis: The WA Liberal Party's candidate in the Rockingham by-election apologises for asking a constituent to question his opponent whether she would resign from parliament if she fell pregnant.

title.children: Scheme to ask by-election rival about her pregnancy plans ends in 'regret' from Liberal candidate

image.altText: Vapour pours from a mill chimney behind power poles.

props.synopsis: Western Australia confirms it will be the only state to not set an emissions reduction target for 2030, despite having the most work to do to bring its carbon output down.

title.children: There's one state where carbon emissions have risen since 2005. It's also the only one with no 2030 reduction target

image.altText: Tennis fans cool off at the Australian Open.

props.synopsis: As Australia prepares for hot and dry months after the declaration of an El Niño, a stark reminder of the increasing danger posed by heatwaves in Australia's southern cities may lie ahead.

title.children: El Niño is likely to bring a scorching summer. These cities might feel it most

image.altText: Anthony Albanese putting on a mask at a press conference.

props.synopsis: An inquiry has been announced into the state, territory and federal governments' response to the COVID-19 pandemic.

title.children: Government announces inquiry into federal, state and territory response to pandemic

image.altText: An illustration of a SARS-CoV-2 virus particle showing the protruding spike proteins on the virus's surface.

props.synopsis: A new COVID variant nicknamed "Pirola" has been detected in Australia after sparking a sped-up vaccination program in the United Kingdom.

title.children: The 'highly mutated' COVID variant BA.2.86 — known as Pirola — has landed in Australia

image.altText: A man's hands

props.synopsis: Peter says when he spoke up about what his primary school teacher had done decades before, he smiled for the first time in years. He's one of a growing number of men coming forward to get help, according to a WA support service.

title.children: More male survivors of sexual assault are seeking help — but specialised support services are hard to find

props.synopsis: Five years ago, LeBron James set out to fix some of America's most difficult problems. Some question whether the project is living up to its promises.

title.children: LeBron James set out to revolutionise America’s broken school system. Then the results came in

image.altText: A small brown Malleefowl chick ina mans hands

props.synopsis: The chicken-sized, chick-abandoning birds have one thing in common with the tiny bush town trying to save them.

title.children: Inside the fight to save a little town and its vulnerable bird population

image.altText: Anonymous woman lies in a bed with heart rate monitor clipped on finger at the Marie Stopes clinic in Melbourne.

props.synopsis: After being unchanged for almost 25 years, Western Australia's abortion laws will be updated as landmark reforms pass the state's parliament.

title.children: Landmark reforms to WA's abortion laws pass state parliament

image.altText: The silhouette of a power station is seen against the sky in the early evening, with thick smoke billowing from three towers.

props.synopsis: There are growing safety concerns at Yallourn Power Station in Victoria, one of Australia's biggest coal-fired power plants. Experts say that could be bad news heading into a long, hot summer.

title.children: Dark clouds gather over one of Australia's biggest coal plants as El Niño heats the land

image.altText: Ukrainian President Volodymyr Zelenskyy addresses a high level Security Council meeting.

props.synopsis: Ukraine President Volodymyr Zelenskyy takes the floor at the UN Security Council to lash 'criminal' Russia before foreign secretary Sergei Lavrov unloads for Russia.

title.children: As Russia ignores Zelenskyy at UN, Ukraine calls for stripping of Russia's veto power

image.altText: Airbnb logo on a pink background with silhouetted figurines of travellers with bags in the foreground

props.synopsis: If there's a lesson from the evolution of the gig economy, it's that we don't yet know how AI will disrupt our economy and our lives. But it's at least worth considering potential impacts and contemplating sensible rules of the road early on, writes David Speers.

title.children: Eight years ago, Airbnb was a new platform with a hidden dark side. Now the warnings are sounding again

image.altText: Von der Leyen can be seen in focus in between soldiers

props.synopsis: A former musician who was once forced to go into hiding from terrorists, European Commission President Ursula von der Leyen's path to power has been an incredible journey.

title.children: How a young girl destined to become a 'housewife at the side of a powerful man' instead grew up to lead Europe through crisis

image.altText: George RR Martin

props.synopsis: This morning's news, as it happens.

title.children: Game of Thrones author George RR Martin sues OpenAI for 'systematic theft', Australia urges US to let Julian Assange walk free. Get in The Loop

liveBlogPostPrepared.plaintext: Australia has officially signed the world's first treaty to protect the high seas and their marine biodiversity. High seas are international waters that aren't controlled by any nation, and make up two-thirds of the world's oceans and cover half of the Earth's surface. That means there are almost no safeguards and they're heavily exposed to over-exploitation. Until now. Foreign Minister Penny Wong put pen to paper overnight at the UN General Assembly in New York. She says Australia will work with Pacific countries to support them to also sign the treaty. The treaty aims to achieve more cooperative management of global fisheries and deal with pollution threats. It will take effect after 60 countries ratify the agreement. Nations that sign on will have to assess the environmental impacts of any planned activities beyond their jurisdictions.
liveBlogPostPrepared.title: Australia signs first-ever global treaty to protect the high seas

children.content: Australia has officially signed the world's first treaty to protect the high seas and their marine biodiversity.
High seas are international waters that aren't controlled by any nation, and make up two-thirds of the world's oceans and cover half of the Earth's surface.
The highlighted areas represent the world's high seas.
(ABC News)
That means there are almost no safeguards and they're heavily exposed to over-exploitation. Until now.
Foreign Minister Penny Wong put pen to paper overnight at the UN General Assembly in New York.
She says Australia will work with Pacific countries to support them to also sign the treaty.
The treaty aims to achieve more cooperative management of global fisheries and deal with pollution threats.
It will take effect after 60 countries ratify the agreement.
Nations that sign on will have to assess the environmental impacts of any planned activities beyond their jurisdictions.

liveBlogPostPrepared.plaintext: Prime Minister Anthony Albanese says the purpose of the government's inquiry into Australia's COVID-19 response is to better prepare for the future. "We said before the election — and I've said since — given the enormous dislocation, the stress, the loss of life, the economic impact of the pandemic, it is appropriate that when we reached a certain period that we would have an inquiry," he says. "We need to examine what could be done better, with a focus on the future. "Because the health experts and the science tells us that this pandemic may well be — indeed is — not likely to be the last one that occurs." He says support for people impacted by pandemic lockdowns will be a part of the review. Health Minister Mark Butler says it will help build the Centre for Disease Control, which will be a "very important part" of preparing for the next pandemic.
liveBlogPostPrepared.title: PM says inquiry into COVID-19 response will prepare Australia for future pandemics

children.content: Prime Minister Anthony Albanese says the purpose of the government's inquiry into Australia's COVID-19 response is to better prepare for the future.

"We said before the election — and I've said since — given the enormous dislocation, the stress, the loss of life, the economic impact of the pandemic, it is appropriate that when we reached a certain period that we would have an inquiry," he says.
"We need to examine what could be done better, with a focus on the future.
"Because the health experts and the science tells us that this pandemic may well be — indeed is — not likely to be the last one that occurs."
He says support for people impacted by pandemic lockdowns will be a part of the review.
Health Minister Mark Butler says it will help build
the Centre for Disease Control, which will be a "very important part" of preparing for the next pandemic.

liveBlogPostPrepared.plaintext: By David Speers Former Liberal treasurer Josh Frydenberg is expected to confirm today he is not seeking a return to politics at the next election. He has taken a new position as the chair of investment bank Goldman Sachs for Australia and New Zealand. Mr Frydenberg has been with Goldman Sachs as senior regional adviser for the Asia Pacific since 2022, after he lost the Melbourne seat of Kooyong to independent Monique Ryan.
liveBlogPostPrepared.title: Former treasurer Josh Frydenberg set to announce decision not to run at next election

children.content: By David Speers
Former Liberal treasurer Josh Frydenberg is expected to confirm today he is not seeking a return to politics at the next election.
(AAP: James Ross)
He has taken a new position as the chair of investment bank Goldman Sachs for Australia and New Zealand.
Mr Frydenberg has been with Goldman Sachs as senior regional adviser for the Asia Pacific since 2022, after he lost the Melbourne seat of Kooyong to independent Monique Ryan.

image.altText: A fair-haired Italian man and a dark-haired Italian man sit on rocks in a mountainous landscape eating bread with their hands.

props.synopsis: This Cannes Jury Prize-winning film set in the scenic Italian Alps is travel-porn worthy – but its central narrative about friendship and the loss of youthful idealism has clout.

title.children: 'Handsome Italians in chunky knitwear': This award-winning, wistful film oozes rustic chic

image.altText: A teenage boy and girl, dressed in colourful clothes, walk their bikes as they chat outside school.

props.synopsis: The British sex comedy has portrayed the teenage experience with nuance and humour. Here's everything you need to know before pressing play on the final season.

title.children: The final season of Sex Education has arrived. Here's everything you need to know before saying goodbye

image.altText: Kylie Minogue sits on a red chair in a yard with dancers.

props.synopsis: We're barrelling towards the end of the year which can only mean one thing: it's ARIA Awards season.

title.children: ARIA Awards 2023 nominations - everything you need to know

image.altText: a man in an office with documents

props.synopsis: Former chair of the ACCC to oversee an inquiry into Price Gouging and Unfair Pricing Practices, while a fall on Wall Street sends Australian stocks lower today. Follow the latest updates in our live blog.

title.children: Former ACCC chair Fels probes price gouging, US Fed holds interest rates steady, ASX falls

liveBlogPostPrepared.plaintext: Mike McNess has told the inquiry Qantas airfares have jumped 32 per cent since pre-COVID levels. "Paying a third more for a ticket wouldn't be justified even if standards had improved. "When safety and services have nosedived, workers have been illegality outsourced and wages of those that remain have been slashed, passengers should not be seeing increases to ticket prices, these prices should be halved."
liveBlogPostPrepared.title: Calls for Qantas ticket prices to be cheaper, not more expensive

children.content: Mike McNess
has told the inquiry
Qantas
airfares have
jumped 32 per cent since pre-COVID levels.
"Paying a third more for a ticket wouldn't be justified even if standards had improved.
"When safety and services have nosedived, workers have been illegality outsourced and wages of those that remain have been slashed, passengers should not be seeing increases to ticket prices,
these prices should be halved."

liveBlogPostPrepared.plaintext: The TWU's, Mike McNess is speaking about Qantas to the price gouging inquiry taking place in Melbourne today. Meantime, Qantas Chairman Richard Goyder has just confirmed with my colleague Peter Ryan that he will front Senate inquiry into aviation next week. We'll bring you a bit more on that shortly.
liveBlogPostPrepared.title: Qantas Chairman Richard Goyder will front Senate inquiry next week

children.content: The TWU's,
Mike McNess is speaking about Qantas to the price gouging inquiry taking place in Melbourne today.
Meantime,
Qantas Chairman Richard Goyder
has just confirmed with my colleague Peter Ryan that
he will front Senate inquiry into aviation next week
We'll bring you a bit more on that shortly.

liveBlogPostPrepared.plaintext: "While we are really feeling this in the cities, it is the regional and rural areas suffer most at a time of crisis, " Ms Thistleton told the inquiry. "When you already have decreased competition, the increased costs of getting fruit and vegetables transported to these areas mean the prices become unmanageable for anyone. On top of that in many remote and indigenous communities', price gouging has just become a really unfortunate part of every day life." She pointed to some research by the National Indigenous Australians Agency that people in those communities are paying up to 40 per cent more for supermarket goods than people in capital cities. Some example she gave were a box of cornflakes for $12 and a small jar of vegemite for $13.
liveBlogPostPrepared.title: Regional and rural areas suffer most at a time of crisis

children.content: "While we are really feeling this in the cities, it is the
regional and rural areas suffer most at a time of crisis,
" Ms Thistleton told the inquiry.
"When you already have decreased competition, the increased costs of getting fruit and vegetables transported to these areas mean the prices become unmanageable for anyone.
On top of that in many remote and indigenous communities', price gouging has just become a really unfortunate part of every day life."
She pointed to some research by the
National Indigenous Australians Agency
that people in those communities are
paying up to 40 per cent more
for supermarket goods than people in capital cities.
Some example she gave were a box of cornflakes for $12 and a small jar of vegemite for $13.

image.altText: Bomb remains in dirt next to small signs with skull and crossbones on them.

props.synopsis: In a letter to the US government, a UN torture expert says cluster munitions — which are prohibited by more than 100 countries — "indiscriminately and seriously injure civilians both at the time of use and in post-conflict" and should not be used.

title.children: US urged not to give Ukraine weapons which could 'remain dangerous for decades'

image.altText: The six politicians stand in front of the US Capitol building.

props.synopsis: An unlikely coalition of Australian parliamentarians converges on Washington to lobby US decision-makers to drop the legal pursuit of Julian Assange and grant his freedom by Christmas.

image.altText: an aboriginal man wearing traditional dress

title.children: 'No consent': Arnhem Land elder calls for Fair Australia to retract his image from campaign material

image.altText: Electricians place solar panels on roof

image.altText: A night vision image of a pet cat carrying native prey in it's mouth.

image.altText: Collingwood's Mason Cox leaps high and takes the ball in one hand at a contest as players stand around.

title.children: This town only has enough jobs for 15 per cent of locals. The community is working to change that

image.altText: Eddie Jones looks pensive after the Wallabies lost to Fiji at the 2023 Rugby World Cup.

image.altText: The silhouette of a firefighter is seen in front of a large bushfire burning high into trees.

image.altText: Wind turbines are set to dot the landscape in Victoria's west

image.altText: Man in a suit stands for his bail hearing in front of a crowd of photograpers.

props.synopsis: Oscar Pistorius was eligible for parole in March and the double-amputee Olympic runner may have been wrongly denied early release from prison because of an error.

title.children: Oscar Pistorius may have been wrongly denied parole over error

image.altText: Novak Djokovic and Rafael Nadal pose for a photograph ahead of the 2022 French Open final.

props.synopsis: Rafael Nadal pays tribute to Novak Djokovic after the world number one added a 24th major singles trophy to his collection following his victory in the US Open final last week.

title.children: 'Best in history': Nadal heaps praise on rival Djokovic
